home: you want to dance with the Stanford band
you've never been to a hackathon
you go to hackathons every weekend
you want to meet people from all over the world
you've never written a line of code in your life
you have ideas you want to make into reality

verticals.name: ar/vr
verticals.description: The physical world is no longer the end-all be-all of human experiences. The AR/VR challenge pushes hackers to create their own realities and the tools necessary to experience them in order to tackle a breadth of problems and push the boundaries of human experiences.

verticals.name: education
verticals.description: Globally, systems and styles of education are evolving everyday, incorporating developments ranging from technology to behavioral science. The education challenge supports hackers in creating new tools for learning and knowledge-sharing across regional borders, language barriers, learning styles, degrees of privilege, and more.

verticals.name: medical access
verticals.description: Almost half a billion people across the world still lack access to basic healthcare, disproportionately affecting marginalized communities even in wealthier regions. The medical access challenge pushes hackers to explore accessibility of treatments, innovate in the rapidly growing field of telemedicine, and redefine healthcare as we know it.

verticals.name: geospatial
verticals.description: Every second, we collect terabytes of traffic, satellite, and location data. The geospatial challenge pushes hackers to utilize rich datasets and APIs to better help and understand the world we live in.

verticals.name: iot
verticals.description: The world has 4.5 billion people connected to the internet – but data tells us there are still 700+ billion unconnected things in our society. The IoT challenge encourages hackers to connect devices in novel ways, collect interesting data, and utilize our vast network of things to make the world a better place.

verticals.name: voice assistance
verticals.description: With the rise of products like Alexa and Siri, voice assistants are increasingly an integral part of day-to-day life in homes, schools, workplaces, and more. The voice assistance challenge encourages hackers to push the boundaries of voice assistant functionalities, address key privacy concerns, and place more power in the hands of users.

about_intro: Join us as we build apps, hardware, and community in the California sun!
about_body: Sure, we’ll be hacking for 36 hours straight, but we’ll also take yoga breaks and play laser tag. Whether you’re a seasoned veteran or just getting started, we’ve got your back every step of the way. Don’t forget your sunscreen!

projects.title: Computertop Desk
projects.description: Omar combined a webcam and projector mounted above a desk, along with a splash of OpenCV to locate all the pieces of paper and the keyboard, allowing users to set any piece of paper as a window for the computer. Omar won Most Creative Hack and Best Hardware Hack at TreeHacks 2018.

projects.title: NeuralHash
projects.description: Isaac, Nikhil, Evani, and Rohan used machine learning to develop a decoder model that acts as a cryptographically-secure, transformation-invariant hash function to identify image ownership. This team won the Security Grand Prize and Most Technically Complex Hack at TreeHacks 2018.

projects.title: #PowerHouse
projects.description: Nadya, Lucy, and Diane learned React Native and honed their UI skills while developing an app that informs users about the energy saving costs of various appliances and helps a user select all desired appliances for a home. TreeHacks 2018 was their first hackathon.

projects.title: The Ultimate Water Heater
projects.description: Matthew and Amarinder built a heating system and a mobile app to build an accessible water heater that has 90% energy efficiency and could save 5 gallons of water per average shower. They won Most Interdisciplinary Hack and Greatest Impact Hack at TreeHacks 2018.

projects.title: Docodial
projects.description: Jenny and Aidan developed a live-streaming web app that allows doctors to communicate with interpreters, empowering non-native speakers to get the health coverage they need. They won Best User Interface and Best Live Video App at TreeHacks 2018.

projects.title: Marvel Medical Dictionary
projects.description: Jomo, Kaleb, Ryan, and Khalid built a mobile, augmented reality experience that allows children to learn about health topics from a superhero related to the searched topic. Imagine Spider-Man teaching about spider bites! They won Best Mobile AR Hack at TreeHacks 2018.

faq.a: A hackathon is where you turn your crazy ideas into real projects. We provide hardware, mentors, fun activities, speakers, workshops, food, friends, and so much more. You take care of hacking; we’ll take care of you.

TreeHacks applications are open to any enrolled college student (undergrad or grad) from all over the world. All current Stanford students that register by appropriate deadlines will be guaranteed admission.

faq.q: What if I don’t know how to code?
faq.a: TreeHacks is the perfect time and place to learn. We provide starter code “hack packs,” as well as beginner-friendly workshops and mentors to help you build something you can be proud of.

faq.q: What if I don’t have a team or idea?
faq.a: Not a problem! We’ll have team-forming activities to help you find teammates and idea brainstorming sessions for all our verticals. Some of our best hacks have been from teams that met and formed an idea on the spot!

Anything your heart desires! Hardware, web, mobile, gaming, VR...you name it, we’ll support it. We have three verticals that will have extra resources, sponsored challenges, and even a CTF to inspire you.

TreeHacks is free for all admitted hackers. We provide meals, caffeine, swag, workspace, and WiFi for the weekend; travel reimbursements & bussing will also be available for qualifying hackers. We're committed to making TreeHacks accessible!

faq.q: What is the TreeHacks code of conduct?
faq.textAfter: , adapted from the Hack Code of Conduct. Every TreeHacks applicant must agree to this Code of Conduct to be considered for admission. TreeHacks is a safe place where everyone is welcome <3.
